My Peak Flow Today Is... Submit You must enter a value for peak flow Well Unwell Emergency Calendar and Graph My Data App Settings Medical Reference Edit Today\'s peak flow has been changed to: Peak flow submitted: Symptoms
Relief Symptoms Your PB Peak Flow (PEF) If you are wheezing, take a puff of your reliever inhaler. If your chest feels tight, take a puff of your reliever inhaler. If you feel breathless, take a puff of your reliever inhaler. If you a constantly coughing, take a puff of your reliever inhaler. If you are struggling to walk, take a puff of your reliever inhaler.
This is what i can do to get on top of my asthma... Start using preventer inhaler regularly Take reliever puffs as needed (up to 3 puffs every 4 hours) If no improvement within 48 hours i should make an urgent appointment to see my GP or asthma nurse. PlaceHolder If you are struggling to sleep, take up to 3 reliever puffs every 4 hours. If you are struggling to talk, take up to 3 reliever puffs every 4 hours. If your peak flow has dropped significantly, take up to 3 reliever puffs every 4 hours.
THIS IS AN EMERGENCY TAKE ACTION NOW Sit up straight. Try to keep calm. Puff Reliever inhaler every time the bar fills Start Timer I dont feel better Get Ready.. Puff!
Next Update Previous
The information on this page is required for the app to help you effectively: The information you enter on this page allows the app to help you effectively: > Name: Age: Gender: Height:
Welcome to AsthmaAid! Though care has been taken to provide information as accurately as possible, this app should not be used to replace professional medical advice. Any information you provide to the app is used to provide more helpful information to you, and is not be shared with any third party.

Your peak flow measurement can indicate how your asthma is responding to treatment. Please enter your personal best below. Personal Best Peak Flow: Warning Peak Flow: Critical Peak Flow: If you have been provided with peak flow values that warn you when you need more treatment, or are having an asthma attack please enter these below. Please enter the date of your annual checkup
Having the details of your GP, asthma nurse and who to contact out of hours saved to your phone can help you in an emergency. GP/Asthma Nurse Out of Hours Contact Name: Phone Number:
Please enter the details of your inhalers and other medication, and the usage you have been recommended. Your Preventer Inhaler: Your Reliever Inhaler: Recommended morning preventer puffs Recommended evening preventer puffs Recommended reliever puffs

Select any from the following which trigger your asthma:
Animals Dust or Dust Mites Emotional Responses Exercise Foods Pollen Smoke Stress Strong Odours Viral Infections Weather or Temperature Change
You can enter any other triggers you may know of here.

Peak Flow Levels: Personal Best Warning Critical * values have been calculated based on your initial setup answers
Dr Details: Appointment Doctor/GP Out of Hours
Medication: Preventer Reliever
Triggers:
Symptoms
Breathing Difficulty If you are having difficulty breathing then you should start using your reliever inhaler.\n\nThis symptom could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
Coughing If you haven’t been using your preventer inhaler, start using it regularly again and take your reliever inhaler as needed.\n\nIf you don’t improve within 48 hours make an urgent appointment to see your GP or asthma nurse.\n\nIf this symptom worsens then it could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
Exercising Difficulty If you haven’t been using your preventer inhaler, start using it regularly again and take your reliever inhaler as needed.\n\nIf you don’t improve within 48 hours make an urgent appointment to see your GP or asthma nurse.
Talking Difficulty If you are having difficulty talking then you should start using your reliever inhaler.\n\nThis symptom could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
Tight Chest If you haven’t been using your preventer inhaler, start using it regularly again and take your reliever inhaler as needed.\n\nIf you don’t improve within 48 hours make an urgent appointment to see your GP or asthma nurse.\n\nIf this symptom worsens then it could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
Walking Difficulty If you are having difficulty waliking then you should start using your reliever inhaler.\n\nThis symptom could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
Waking at Night If you haven’t been using your preventer inhaler, start using it regularly again and take your reliever inhaler as needed.\n\nIf you don’t improve within 48 hours make an urgent appointment to see your GP or asthma nurse.
Wheezing If you haven’t been using your preventer inhaler, start using it regularly again and take your reliever inhaler as needed.\n\nIf you don’t improve within 48 hours make an urgent appointment to see your GP or asthma nurse.\n\nIf this symptom worsens then it could be a precursor to an asthma attack and you should refer to the emergency information.
